metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: AngularJS Application
It is time to create a real AngularJS Application.
content.html: It is time to create a real AngularJS Application.

content.text: Make a Shopping List
Lets use some of the AngularJS features to make a shopping list, where you can add or remove items:
content.html: Lets use some of the AngularJS features to make a shopping list, where you can add or remove items:

content.text: My Shopping List
Application Explained
Step 1. Getting Started:
Start by making an application called myShoppingList , and add a controller named myCtrl to it.
content.html: Start by making an application called myShoppingList, and add a controller named myCtrl to it.

content.text: The controller adds an array named products to the current $scope .
content.html: The controller adds an array named products to the current $scope.

content.text: In the HTML, we use the ng-repeat directive to display a list using the items in the array.
content.html: In the HTML, we use the ng-repeat directive to display a list using the items in the array.

content.code_html:
<script>
var app = angular.module("myShoppingList", []);
app.controller("myCtrl", function($scope) {
  $scope.products = ["Milk", "Bread", "Cheese"];
});
</script>

<div ng-app="myShoppingList" ng-controller="myCtrl">
  <ul>
    <li ng-repeat="x in products">{{x}}</li>
  </ul>
</div>

content.text: Step 2. Adding Items:
In the HTML, add a text field, and bind it to the application with the ng-model directive.
content.html: In the HTML, add a text field, and bind it to the application with the ng-model directive.

content.text: In the controller, make a function named addItem , and use the value of the addMe input field to add an item to the products array.
content.html: In the controller, make a function named addItem, and use the value of the addMe input field to add an item to the products array.

content.text: Add a button, and give it an ng-click directive that will run the addItem function when the button is clicked.
content.html: Add a button, and give it an ng-click directive that will run the addItem function when the button is clicked.

content.code_html:
<script>
var app = angular.module("myShoppingList", []);
app.controller("myCtrl", function($scope) {
  $scope.products = ["Milk", "Bread", "Cheese"];
  $scope.addItem = function () {
    $scope.products.push($scope.addMe);
  }
});
</script>

<div ng-app="myShoppingList" ng-controller="myCtrl">
  <ul>
    <li ng-repeat="x in products">{{x}}</li>
  </ul>
  <input ng-model="addMe">
  <button ng-click="addItem()">Add</button>
</div>

content.text: Step 3. Removing Items:
We also want to be able to remove items from the shopping list.
content.html: We also want to be able to remove items from the shopping list.

content.text: In the controller, make a function named removeItem , which takes the index of the item you want to remove, as a parameter.
content.html: In the controller, make a function named removeItem, which takes the index of the item you want to remove, as a parameter.

content.text: In the HTML, make a <span> element for each item, and give them an ng-click directive which calls the removeItem function with the current $index .
content.html: In the HTML, make a <span> element for each item, and give them an ng-click directive which calls the removeItem function with the current $index.

content.code_html:
<script>
var app = angular.module("myShoppingList", []);
app.controller("myCtrl", function($scope) {
  $scope.products = ["Milk", "Bread", "Cheese"];
  $scope.addItem = function () {
    $scope.products.push($scope.addMe);
  }
  $scope.removeItem = function (x) {
    $scope.products.splice(x, 1);
  }
});
</script>

<div ng-app="myShoppingList" ng-controller="myCtrl">
  <ul>
    <li ng-repeat="x in products">
      {{x}}<span ng-click="removeItem($index)">×</span>
    </li>
  </ul>
  <input ng-model="addMe">
  <button ng-click="addItem()">Add</button>
</div>

content.text: Step 4. Error Handling:
The application has some errors, like if you try to add the same item twice, the application crashes. Also, it should not be allowed to add empty items.
content.html: The application has some errors, like if you try to add the same item twice, the application crashes. Also, it should not be allowed to add empty items.

content.text: We will fix that by checking the value before adding new items.
content.html: We will fix that by checking the value before adding new items.

content.text: In the HTML, we will add a container for error messages, and write an error message when someone tries to add an existing item.
content.html: In the HTML, we will add a container for error messages, and write an error message when someone tries to add an existing item.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
"The item is already 
    in your shopping list."

syntax_highlighting.text:
"The item is already 
    in your shopping list."

content.code_html:
<script>
var app = angular.module("myShoppingList", []);
app.controller("myCtrl", function($scope) {
  $scope.products = ["Milk", "Bread", "Cheese"];
  $scope.addItem = function () {
    $scope.errortext = "";
    if (!$scope.addMe) {return;}
    if ($scope.products.indexOf($scope.addMe) == -1) {
      $scope.products.push($scope.addMe);
    } else {
      $scope.errortext = "The item is already in your shopping list.";
    }
  }
  $scope.removeItem = function (x) {
    $scope.errortext = "";
    $scope.products.splice(x, 1);
  }
});
</script>

<div ng-app="myShoppingList" ng-controller="myCtrl">
  <ul>
    <li ng-repeat="x in products">
      {{x}}<span ng-click="removeItem($index)">×</span>
    </li>
  </ul>
  <input ng-model="addMe">
  <button ng-click="addItem()">Add</button>
  <p>{{errortext}}</p>
</div>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
"The item is already 
    in your shopping list."

content.text: Step 5. Design:
The application works, but could use a better design. We use the W3.CSS stylesheet to style our application.
content.html: The application works, but could use a better design. We use the W3.CSS stylesheet to style our application.

content.text: Add the W3.CSS stylesheet, and include the proper classes throughout the application, and the result will be the same as the shopping list at the top of this page.
content.html: Add the W3.CSS stylesheet, and include the proper classes throughout the application, and the result will be the same as the shopping list at the top of this page.

content.code_html: <link rel="stylesheet" href="https://www.w3schools.com/w3css/4/w3.css">
